text.sentence: Basic Industries | U.S. Metals and Mining twenty nine February two thousand sixteen

We were pleased to host a series of investor meetings in California last week with CF Industries: Participants included President/CEO Tony Will, CFO Dennis Kelleher, SVP of Sales, Distribution, and Marketing Bert Frost, and the IR team led by Dan Aldridge.

In our view, the further along that CF's growth and market strategies progress, the better the company's story appears: The CHS deal has closed, the OCI transaction is moving toward completion in threeQ, and the major organic expansions will ramp up over the rest of two thousand sixteen.

Though currency issues and urea pricing have been front of mind in the market for months, it's been our view that as CF's strategic pieces move into place and capex spending winds down, the company's key investment proposition ­ a favorable cash flow profile underpinned by low gas costs and an industry leading production and distribution platform ­ will again emerge.
We found it a good sign that the buyside inquiries on this trip centered more on CF's production mix decisions, export prospects, and tax details than on speculation over FX or natural gas prices.

CF's executives added useful color on how a pro forma CF/OCI will operate: As investors have had time to digest the several pieces of the inversion/asset combination, we've seen investor pushback fade.

Will, Kelleher, and Frost are helping this process by clarifying more details on the deal timeline, on the post transaction tax rate, on the opportunities from a combined GrowHo with Geleen production system in Europe, and on the current hurdles facing the Natgasoline project.

China's behavior as the world's marginal nitrogen producer remains the biggest risk to the stock: A weaker RMB, collapsed freight costs, and low coal prices have enabled China to export urea at an ever lower breakeven cost.
Similar risks exist for other materials where China is net long; CF's differentiation is in its profitability level even at reduced realizations.

CF remains well positioned as a global nitrogen producer advantaged by low cost North American natural gas, and we believe the company will benefit financially and strategically from its pending deal with OCI.
While investors understandably focus on near term commodity price risks out of China, CF's margins and cash flow generation should rebound.
forward multiple applied to a projected two thousand seventeen EBITDA of dollar two.eightB, which assumes higher nitrogen pricing.
Our downside case of dollar twenty one uses a six.x forward multiple applied to a projected two thousand seventeen EBITDA of dollar one.eightB,

Income statement Revenue EBITDA EBIT Pre tax income Net income EPS Diluted shares DPS Margin and return data EBITDA margin EBIT margin Pre tax margin Net margin ROIC ROA ROE Balance sheet and cash flow Tangible fixed assets Intangible fixed assets Cash and equivalents Total assets Short and long term debt Other long term liabilities Total liabilities Net debt/ Shareholders' equity Change in working capital Cash flow from operations Capital expenditure Equity free cash flow Valuation and leverage metrics P/E EV/EBITDA Equity FCF yield P/Sales P/BV Dividend yield Total debt/capital Selected operating metrics Sales volume Phosphate Average price Phosphate Sales volume Nitrogen Average price Nitrogen
It's good to be in California in February, especially while urea prices are recovering
In spending time with CF Industries' top management last week, we heard the following themes emerge over and over again: one.
Under current conditions, CF's business is still generating ample gross margins and healthy cash flow.

Even assuming no profound improvement in market conditions the company's capital allocation options open up as capex winds down, production scale and diversity increases, and share repurchases become viable again after the OCI transaction closes.
Our own estimates bear this out; we assume all in nitrogen pricing falls by over fourteen percent in two thousand sixteen vs. two thousand fifteen and then remains essentially flat.

Still CF's FCF yield should move from sixteen percent in two thousand fifteen to +thirteen percent by two thousand seventeen ­ and our model does not include pro forma OCI effects, which we estimate to be accretive to cash flow per share.
CF's market position is much more stable than many in the market understand it to be.

Two items here particularly interested us: First, as we've long emphasized, the long assumed build out of North American nitrogen capacity that attracted so much attention when projects were announced in the hey days of two thousand twelve has largely shrunk to the build out of CF capacity ­ Donaldsonville, Port Neal, and Wever/OCI.

CF's investor presentation, shows that even after including these plants and the four new plants aimed at industrial use, a pro forma two thousand fifteen U.S. nitrogen import total would have still been a healthy seven.fourmm

Given a three five year development period and economics that don't support greenfield projects, the prospect of a balanced or net long U.S. nitrogen market that decouples from global pricing levels is highly unlikely in the near to medium term.

Second, by folding in the Wever plant and combining the capabilities of Donaldsonville with the Dubai based, tax advantaged trading platform, CF should be able to protect its regional premiums within North America.
A Wever that is under the control of CF and has access to CF's distribution network will be a more disciplined asset than it would have been under OCI.
As an OCI plant Wever would have had much less market access, and in response it would likely have been more aggressive on pricing.

With Donaldsonville soon capable of exporting millions of tons of product via the taxfree entity in Dubai ­ potentially bringing after tax margins on export sales in line with domestic sales, CF's ability to advantageously manage and balance the domestic market will be substantially increased.
CF filed its ten K as of February twenty fiveth, and the company is waiting for OCI to file its year end financials in the near term.
After this is done, CF will re submit an updated Sfour with the SEC expecting a relatively quick turnaround .
The company will then issue a forty two day notice of its shareholder meeting, hold its meeting, and then wait out a sixty day period according to Dutch law.
This all implies an expected closing date in July or August two thousand sixteen.

As we discussed in our note from last Friday, A first glimpse at USDA's two thousand sixteen/ seventeen forecasts... February twenty six, two thousand sixteen, the arrival of warm weather early this year after many growers were prevented
Barclays | CF Industries Holdings from putting sufficient nitrogen down in the form of ammonia last fall is expected to lead to healthy sales of urea and UAN in the spring.

Our impression from trade publications, industry sources, and the tenor of CF management's commentary last week is that product is moving well as March approaches, and that inventories are sufficient for the first round of applications in most regions.
If the season progresses without any weather disruptions, the regional distribution system will need to perform very efficiently
The short summary of all the items above is this: CF is as well positioned in its industry as any company that we cover.
The challenge for investors is whether the stock can get credit for a leading share in what's still a commodity market until the China/global growth/FX fears fade.
Fears of the effects of a yuan devaluation are widespread well beyond the materials stocks in our universe.
For those commodities where China is net long, a weaker CNY:USD implies a flatter cost curve.
For those where China is short, the worry is that demand will weaken and bring down the price.
If you have a negative view on the direction of the CNY, you're generally not going to find attraction in the raw materials sector or CF stock.
That said, we see reason to be encouraged for those looking for high quality names within a heavily beaten down sector.
CF has absorbed investor concerns around tax inversion rules and adapted accordingly .
The CHS deal is complete, adding dollar two.eight billion in cash to the company's balance sheet at a very favorable implied valuation.

The OCI deal is within sight, and with project financing for the Natgasoline project likely difficult for OCI to achieve, CF's methanol exposure may wind up to be much less than some investors had feared.

With catalysts over two thousand sixteen including the anticipated threeQ OCI deal closure and the potential restart of share buybacks, we remain Overweight on CF shares and look forward to the time when the company returns to its previous wheelhouse of selling more nitrogen, buying back shares, and repeating.
NOTE: We do not include OCI pro forma effects in our current estimates, but call us and we're happy to walk through those scenarios or any other details regarding our models.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: Our dollar forty three price target reflects a weighted average of two valuation methodologies: a six.fivex
EV multiple on our two thousand seventeenE EBITDA estimate of dollar two.twenty three billion, implying a dollar thirty five stock price, and a discounted cash flow model with a WACC of eight.five

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Complications with the pending OCI transaction, an overall slowdown in economic growth, a material shift lower in the cost of Chinese nitrogen production, a spike in natural gas prices, or weaker crop prices that discourage North American planted acreage could cause CF Industries to perform materially lower than our expectations.
